CRUCQ,* L. DEGOLS, A. FRENNET and G. LIENAKD Unite de Recherche sur la Catalyse, University Libre de Bruxelles, Campus Plaine ULB, C.P. 243. Bid. du Triomphe, B-1050 Brussels (Belgium) Summary Supported catalysts containing chlorine originating from the precursor salt used in preparation have been shown previously to exhibit two features towards hydrogen adsorption not found in model catalysts: (1) a very important slow adsorption (2) a very high heat of adsorption at low coverage (strong adsorption). In the present paper, the adsorption of hydrogen is studied on two Rh/AlaOg chlorine-free catalysts: one prepared using ?(N03)3 as precursor; the second one, a previously studied catalyst that has been dechlorinated. It is shown here that both slow and strong adsorption is due mainly to the presence of chlorine. Introduction Studies of adsorption and of catalytic activity may generally be divided into two groups, according to whether the measurements are conducted on model catalysts or on real, practical catalysts. The group of model catalysts comprises all clean unsupported forms of metal single crystals, evaporated films, powders although supported catalysts of low dispersion showing well-defined crystal faces, and in which metal-support interactions are negligible, may also be included in this group. The group of real catalysts comprises only supported catalysts, generally highly dispersed and in which metal-support interactions are important. When studying hydrogen adsorption on platinum group metals, striking differences between model and real catalysts are observed. This is illustrated in the following for the case of rhodium, the metal examined in this paper, but similar facts have been reported for other metals of the Pt group. On Rh model catalysts the adsorption of Ha is characterized by: very high values of the sticking coefficient a: values of a at zero *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 258 coverage, (TO as high as 0.65 are cited for Rh [I], which decrease slowly and in most cases following the law a = (T()(I - 6)2; adsorption is thus rapid. moderate values of the heat of adsorption Q, around 85 kJmol"1 at zero coverage and decreasing to ~29kJmol~1 at coverage around 0.7 [2]. a stoichiometry of adsorption close to 1 adsorbed hydrogen atom per 1 metal surface atom (H/Ms= 1) [2]. On real catalysts, the situation is quite different. Results obtained in our lab [2-5], as well as those of the literature [6] indicate that, quite frequently, the adsorption of Hg may be broken down into a fast and a slow process, adsorption equilibrium being attained after several hours [2 5], the maximum duration found in the literature being 48 h [6]. The amount adsorbed during the slow process may be almost equal to that adsorbed during the fast process [4]. The adsorption heat at low coverage may also be much higher than on model catalysts. By an isosteric analysis of a set of adsorption isotherms at different temperature, we measured values of the heat of adsorption higher than 188kJmor1 at low coverage [4]. This must be related to the so-called 'strong* adsorption of Ha, which has been reviewed recently and which is generally characterized by an abnormally high desorption temperature in thermal desorption experiments [7]. On supported catalysts, values as high as 1.8 [8] have been found for the ratio H/M (the number H of adsorbed hydrogen atoms to the total number of metal atoms M); as M/Mg is necessarily ssl, the ratio H/Mg is thus ^1.8, a stoichiometric ratio much higher than the classical value of 1. In all cases where these abnormal values of sticking coefficient, adsorption heat and H/M are cited in the literature, the catalysts were prepared using chloride as the precursor salt. Recently the influence of chlorine on the chemisorption properties of Ru catalysts was studied by Lu and Tatarchuk [9]; they showed that chlorine may be deposited on a chlorine-free catalyst by treating it with HClaq, and that this treatment has two effects: (1) a fraction of (fast) chemisorption sites is lost; (2) new sites are created on which hydrogen adsorption is slow and activated. In our lab, the adsorption of hydrogen was recently studied on two Rh/AlgOa catalysts prepared from RhCIa by the incipient wetness technique, with different dispersions [4]. These catalysts were also characterized by several other techniques: TPO, TPR, EXAFS, etc. [10-13]. Both catalysts exhibited a very important slow adsorption that was also activated. Equil- ibrium of adsorption could be attained after a reasonable delay, less than half an hour, only by heating the catalyst in the presence of Hg at ~470K. Adsorption heats at low coverage were found to be higher than 190 kJ mol~1 and on the mostly dispersed catalyst, the H/Rh value was 1.45. Although the TPR results indicated that, under the conditions used, the reduction of the metal was complete, the only possible interpretation of these results was that residual chlorine in an unknown chemical form was responsible for the observed effects. After completion of this work [4], it was found that the studied catalysts effectively contained residual chlorine. 259 The object of this paper is to obtain experimental evidence concerning the influence of chlorine on Hz adsorption. Results obtained on a chlorine-free (nitrate precursor) Rh catalyst as well as on a dechlorinated catalyst are reported in this paper and compared with those obtained previously on chlorine-containing catalysts. Experimental Catalysts Two catalysts were studied: (i) a chlorine-free catalyst prepared by the incipient wetness technique from Rh(N03)a as precursor and AlgOa (Alon C Degussa) as support. Rh content was 1.66% by weight. After impregnation the catalyst was first dried in air at 415 K, when under He flux at 673 K during 2 h; the temperature was then reduced to 573 K and He replaced by Ha. Reduction under Ha flux was carried out during 5 h, the catalyst then cooled to room temperature under He flux and introduced in the chemisorption apparatus in the presence of air. Further treatments were carried out in situ and are described later. (ii) a 4.8% Rh/AlaOs whose preparation and properties were described elsewhere, and on which a complete study of Ha chemisorption has been carried out in our lab [8]. After completion of this work, this catalyst was found to contain 1.1% by weight of chlorine (Cl/Rh=0.66) as measured by X-ray fluorescence. Chlorine could be eliminated by washing the catalyst with dilute ammonia solution (0.1 N) at room temperature for 15 h. The residual chlorine content after washing was ~0.05%. After washing, the catalyst was dried at 400 K and introduced in the chemisorption apparatus where the pretreatments previously applied to the original catalyst (oxidation at 573 K under Oa flux, reduction at 673 K under Ha flux) were applied again. Apparatus and procedure for adsorption measurements The apparatus and procedure have already been described [14]. Adsorption measurements were conducted in a fused Pyrex apparatus provided with glass stainless steel bellow valves, by a classical volumetric method. The pressure measuring devices were: a Texas Instruments Bourdon gauge (range either lO^^Otorr or 4xl0-3-1200torr). a differentially mounted system of 2 Pirani gauges (range 10~6- 0.15 torr). Adsorption isotherms measurements were conducted in the desorption mode. All adsorption results are expressed in H/M (here H/Rh) units. Results General: fast and slow adsorptions ofHs The adsorption of Ha on both catalysts at room temperature and lower may be decomposed into a fast process and a slow process. As it takes around 260 30 s to obtain the first pressure measurement after the admission of Hg in the presence of the catalyst, we define, in an empirical way, the 'rapidly adsorbed amount' as the amount adsorbed after 1 min. During the slow process, the increase in the adsorbed amount is proportional to the logarithm of the time [4]. At low temperature, the slow process does not seem to stop after more than 20 h. The real end-point of this slow process is determined in an empirical way by the loss of integrity of the vacuum system that forces the operator to declare at a certain moment that steady state is attained. The amount adsorbed during the slow process generally represents an important fraction of and in some cases is almost equal to the amount adsorbed during the fast process. At 473 K, a slow process is still observed, but it stops after 15 min. The corresponding adsorbed amount represents less than 2% of the amount adsorbed during the fast process. Figure 1 in the form of bar graphs illustrates the relative importance of the fast and slow process for both catalysts studied here (Fig. 1, 2 A B C and 5 A B 0] and by way of comparison for two catalysts previously studied (Fig. 1, 1 A B C and 4 A B C], The procedure used previously is again followed: hydrogen is placed in the presence of the catalyst at 193 K and the adsorbed amounts measured after 1 min (fast process) and after 1 h (slow process) are shown on bar A by white and hatched bars respectively; the whole system is then heated at room temperature during 1 h, then cooled again to 193 K; the corresponding adsorbed amounts at 193 K measured after 1 min and after 1 h are shown on bar B; the whole system is then heated to 473 K, then cooled again to 193 K, at which the same measurements are repeated [bar C]. It must be noted that, as we are in a closed system, with no addition or removal of hydrogen, the equilibrium pressures corresponding to measurements shown by bars A B and C are different. However at 193 K, 120 / E ] Fas tAc ,.J 100- Z7 7 S 3 Slo wA ds| /^ Z7 2 iff y? ^ ffl 80- ^ yy ^ 60- !' g g 40- 2 ' 20- ^ / < / f < ft s- oc 1A1B1C2A2B2C3A3B3C4A4B4C5A5B5C Fig. 1. Fast and slow (activated) adsorption of Hz at 193 K on different rhodium catalysts. 1: 4.80% Kh/ALAi (original catalyst): (H/Rh)n^ = 7.33 x 10-2 (100%); 2: 4.80% Rh/Al^Oa (dechlorinated): (H/Rh)n^ = 5.40 x 10-2 (100%); 3: 4.80% Rh/Al^ (dechlorinated): 100%= 7.33 x 10"2; 4: 1.04% Rh/ALA) (chloride precursor) see [4], (H/Rh)n,^ = 1.45 (100%); 5: 1.66% Rh/Al^Oa (nitrate precursor): (H/Rh)ma*= 1.05 (100%); A: Hz introduction at 193 K; B: after heating at 295 K; C: after heating at 473 K; (see text). 261 as seen later, the adsorption isotherm is almost flat, and the possible influence of the variation in pressure may be neglected. All results in Fig. 1 are expressed in percent of the maximum adsorbed amount (H/Rh)max at 193 K, measured after heating at 473 K. Corresponding absolute values of (H/Rh)max are given in the legend of Fig. 1. The procedure used here is quite similar to the 'temperature jump experiments' made by Lu and Tatarchuk [9] in their study of hydrogen adsorption on Ru catalysts. The comparison between the different catalysts indicates that: (1) on the dechlorinated catalyst, the total adsorbed amount is reduced by -25% (from 7.33 x 10-2 to 5.40 x 10-2 in H/Rh units). (2) this reduction is for the most part due to the reduction of the amount of Hg adsorbed during the slow process. But this process is not completely suppressed. The amount adsorbed during the fast process is 4.54 x 10-2 in H/Rh units. (3) the amounts adsorbed during the fast process on the chlorinated and dechlorinated catalysts are equal, within experimental error: compare 1A and 3A in Fig. 1. (4) on the catalyst prepared from Rh(N03)a, slow adsorption is still very important, representing 45% of the total adsorption, about the same proportion as on the chlorinated samples. In an attempt to clarify the situation concerning the catalyst prepared from Rh(NOa)3, and following the method used for the chlorinated samples in the previous work, we have investigated the effect of reduction temperature on the total adsorption capacity and on the relative importance of the slow process. The reduction temperature was varied from 573 to 973 K. The effect on the relative importance of the slow process is negligible. The effect on total adsorption is also negligible, except at the highest reduction temperature (973 K) where a loss of adsorption capacity of ~20% is observed. This loss is reduced to 10% after oxidation under Og flow at atmospheric pressure and 773 K, followed by reduction at 673 K under Hg flow without influence on the fast/slow adsorption ratio. Adsorption isotherms and heats of adsorption Adsorption isotherms were measured in the desorption mode on both catalysts in a wide range of experimental conditions (193)4: 1.66% Mi/A^Oa. atoms generated on the surface of the metal by dissociative adsorption, no direct experimental evidence is available. Results obtained on the chlorine-free catalyst (nitrate precursor) still require some comments: indeed, a very important slow adsorption is still observed, but the adsorption heats at low coverage, although exhibiting more 'normal' values, are still significantly higher than on model catalysts. We have seen that chlorine originating from the precursor salt used cannot be completely removed from the support even after several steps of calcination and reduction at high temperature, and is responsible for the majority of the strong and slow adsorptions. In a similar way, we suggest that the slow and medium-strong adsorptions of hydrogen on the Rh catalyst prepared using a nitrate precursor are due to the presence of some residual N0^ on the surface. Further work is needed to check this hypothesis. Acknowledgements The authors thank Johnson Matthey PLC for the loan of rhodium nitrate. Thanks are also due to Mr. G. Thiry for his participation in the experimental part of this work and to Dr. P. Duvigneaud (Chimie des Solides ULB) who carried out the X-ray fluorescence analysis. 266 References 1 J. T. Yates, P. coredata.dc:description: Supported catalysts containing chlorine originating from the precursor salt used in preparation have been shown previously to exhibit two features towards hydrogen adsorption not found in model catalysts: (1) a very important slow adsorption (2) a very high heat of adsorption at low coverage (strong adsorption). In the present paper, the adsorption of hydrogen is studied on two Rh/Al2O3 chlorine-free catalysts: one prepared using Rh(NO3)3 as precursor; the second one, a previously studied catalyst that has been dechlorinated. It is shown here that both slow and strong adsorption is due mainly to the presence of chlorine.
coredata.dc:title: Fast, slow and strong adsorption of H2 on Rh/Al2O3 catalysts: effect of chlorine
